unnormalised: ## My Budget Trip to Kerala: Chai, Boats, and a Lot of ₹₹₹
normalised: My Budget Trip to Kerala: Chai, Boats, and a Lot of Rupees

unnormalised: So, I just got back from the most amazing trip to Kerala! Backwaters, spice gardens, Kathakali performances – it was all a bit surreal. But more importantly, I managed to do it all without completely breaking the bank. I thought I'd share my budget breakdown, because everyone deserves a little "God's Own Country" in their life.
normalised: So, I just got back from the most amazing trip to Kerala! Backwaters, spice gardens, Kathakali performances – it was all a bit surreal. But more importantly, I managed to do it all without completely breaking the bank. I thought I'd share my budget breakdown, because everyone deserves a little "God's Own Country" in their life.

unnormalised: First things first, flights. I booked way in advance – think 3 months before – and snagged a round trip from Delhi to Kochi for around Rs. 8,000. Keep an eye out on those flash sales; airlines like Indigo and SpiceJet often have some pretty sweet deals. Also, consider flying on weekdays; Tuesdays and Wednesdays are usually cheaper. My friend Priya paid almost ₹12,000 because she booked just 2 weeks before! Lesson learned.
normalised: First things first, flights. I booked way in advance – think three months before – and snagged a round trip from Delhi to Kochi for around rupee eight thousand. Keep an eye out on those flash sales; airlines like I-N-D-I-G-O and S-P-I-C-E-J-E-T often have some pretty sweet deals. Also, consider flying on weekdays; Tuesdays and Wednesdays are usually cheaper. My friend Priya paid almost rupee twelve thousand because she booked just two weeks before! Lesson learned.

unnormalised: Accommodation was another big chunk of my expenses. I decided to stay in hostels whenever possible. They're a great way to meet other travellers and save a ton of cash. A bed in a decent hostel cost me about ₹500-₹800 per night. Websites like Hostelworld are your best friend for this. Hotels were tempting, especially with those picturesque views, but the budget screamed "hostel life!". I did treat myself to one night in a houseboat on the Alleppey backwaters, which set me back around ₹3,500. Worth every single rupee!
normalised: Accommodation was another big chunk of my expenses. I decided to stay in hostels whenever possible. They're a great way to meet other travellers and save a ton of cash. A bed in a decent hostel cost me about rupee five hundred to rupee eight hundred per night. Websites like Hostelworld are your best friend for this. Hotels were tempting, especially with those picturesque views, but the budget screamed "hostel life!". I did treat myself to one night in a houseboat on the Alleppey backwaters, which set me back around rupee three thousand five hundred. Worth every single rupee!

unnormalised: Getting around Kerala can be tricky. Auto-rickshaws are readily available but be prepared to haggle! Always negotiate the price beforehand; otherwise, you'll end up paying the "tourist tax." Buses are the most economical option. A ride from Kochi to Munnar, which is roughly 130 km, cost me only Rs. 250. Just be prepared for a bumpy ride!
normalised: Getting around Kerala can be tricky. Auto-rickshaws are readily available but be prepared to haggle! Always negotiate the price beforehand; otherwise, you'll end up paying the "tourist tax." Buses are the most economical option. A ride from Kochi to Munnar, which is roughly one hundred and thirty kilometer, cost me only rupee two hundred and fifty. Just be prepared for a bumpy ride!

unnormalised: Food is where Kerala truly shines, and thankfully, it's super affordable. Street food is your best bet for tasty and budget-friendly meals. Dosas, idlis, vada – you can fill your stomach for less than ₹100. Splurging on a proper Keralan thali at a restaurant will cost you around Rs. 300-Rs. 500, but it's an experience you shouldn't miss. Don’t forget the chai breaks! A small cup of chai is just Rs. 10, and it’s the perfect way to recharge after a long day of exploring.
normalised: Food is where Kerala truly shines, and thankfully, it's super affordable. Street food is your best bet for tasty and budget-friendly meals. Dosas, idlis, vada – you can fill your stomach for less than rupee one hundred. Splurging on a proper Keralan thali at a restaurant will cost you around rupee three hundred to rupee five hundred, but it's an experience you shouldn't miss. Don’t forget the chai breaks! A small cup of chai is just rupee ten, and it’s the perfect way to recharge after a long day of exploring.

unnormalised: Activities wise, I tried to find free or low-cost options. Walking around Fort Kochi, exploring the Chinese fishing nets, and visiting local markets didn't cost a thing. For the Kathakali performance, I paid around ₹400. The spice garden tour in Munnar was about Rs. 300. Backwater kayaking cost me around Rs 1,200 for a 3 hour tour.
normalised: Activities wise, I tried to find free or low-cost options. Walking around Fort Kochi, exploring the Chinese fishing nets, and visiting local markets didn't cost a thing. For the Kathakali performance, I paid around rupee four hundred. The spice garden tour in Munnar was about rupee three hundred. Backwater kayaking cost me around rupee one thousand two hundred for a three hour tour.

unnormalised: Souvenirs – everyone wants to bring something back! But that's where budgets often go out the window. I limited myself to buying spices (of course!), some handloom fabrics, and a few small trinkets. I spent around ₹2,000 on souvenirs in total. Remember to bargain hard, especially at the local markets.
normalised: Souvenirs – everyone wants to bring something back! But that's where budgets often go out the window. I limited myself to buying spices (of course!), some handloom fabrics, and a few small trinkets. I spent around rupee two thousand on souvenirs in total. Remember to bargain hard, especially at the local markets.

unnormalised: Overall, my 7-day trip to Kerala cost me approximately ₹20,000. This included flights, accommodation, food, transportation, activities, and souvenirs. Not bad, right? I could have easily spent double that amount if I had opted for fancy hotels and tourist traps.
normalised: Overall, my seven day trip to Kerala cost me approximately rupee twenty thousand. This included flights, accommodation, food, transportation, activities, and souvenirs. Not bad, right? I could have easily spent double that amount if I had opted for fancy hotels and tourist traps.

unnormalised: Some unexpected expenses included: Rs 200 for sunscreen (essential!), Rs 500 for mosquito repellent (trust me, you'll need it), and Rs 300 for tips. Always factor in a buffer for unexpected costs.
normalised: Some unexpected expenses included: rupee two hundred for sunscreen (essential!), rupee five hundred for mosquito repellent (trust me, you'll need it), and rupee three hundred for tips. Always factor in a buffer for unexpected costs.

unnormalised: So there you have it – my budget-friendly guide to Kerala. It proves that you don't need to be a millionaire to experience the beauty and culture of this incredible state. With a little planning and some smart choices, you can have an unforgettable trip without emptying your wallet. Now, time to start planning my next adventure! Maybe Rajasthan? Let me start saving up those Rs. again!
normalised: So there you have it – my budget-friendly guide to Kerala. It proves that you don't need to be a millionaire to experience the beauty and culture of this incredible state. With a little planning and some smart choices, you can have an unforgettable trip without emptying your wallet. Now, time to start planning my next adventure! Maybe Rajasthan? Let me start saving up those rupees again!
